AD_Greeting.synopsis: The expeditioner greets the player characters on sight.

individual_metadata.synopsis: An aging expeditioner gives the player the task of collecting a githyanki egg and debates nature vs. nurture.
individual_metadata.how_to_trigger: Click on the explorer at -47; 52; -133 in CRE_Main.

AD_Greeting_0.speaker: Lady Esther
AD_Greeting_0.text: A curse on every gith. Intransigent louts...

AD_Greeting_1.speaker: Lady Esther
AD_Greeting_1.text: This egg is perfect. The Society will be pleased.

AD_Greeting_2.speaker: Lady Esther
AD_Greeting_2.text: What is taking them so long? Some of us want to leave...

37.speaker: Lady Esther
37.text: At least we can preserve something of that unfortunate crèche.

25.speaker: Player
25.text: Do you have anything to trade?

45.speaker: Lady Esther
45.text: I trust that an early payment has ensured swift action. What news of the githyanki egg?

84.speaker: Lady Esther
84.text: A friendly face! Oh you are a sweet, sweet blessing, my dear.

143.speaker: Lady Esther
143.text: You know, I've had nothing but trouble all day. I've been accosted, chased, insulted.
143.context: NodeContext: Lady Esther is especially bothered by the insults

30.speaker: Lady Esther
30.text: Look over there. Do you see that wretched little hive?
30.context:
CinematicNodeContext: She points to the Monestary of Lathander, which we can see in the distance

(Direction is forward and to the Expeditioner's right, roughly 2 o'clock)

6.speaker: Lady Esther
6.text: Oh it certainly looks that way, but inside it is swarming with brutish, stupid, rude githyanki.
6.context: NodeContext: Again, most offended by the face that they're rude

147.speaker: Lae'zel
147.text: Brutish and rude by your wretched standards. But stupid? K'chakhi.

83.speaker: Lady Esther
83.text: Your charming companion would call it a crèche. But it was built on what remained after the githyanki slaughtered all of the monks. I'd call it a murderous training camp.

8.speaker: Lady Esther
8.text: Honestly, I was doing them a favour, offering to buy one of their eggs. And how am I repaid? Attacked and run off like some transient.

154.speaker: Player
154.text: You tried to buy one of their children?

263.speaker: Lady Esther
263.text: What? No, of course not! I was merely - well...

161.speaker: Player
161.text: Why would you want one of their eggs?

40.speaker: Player
40.text: And? How much did you offer?

221.speaker: Lady Esther
221.text: The Society of Brilliance asked me to acquire one of their roe so they can incubate it and, once it hatches, raise the spawn in their tradition.

57.speaker: Lae'zel
57.text: Please, do enlighten me. What is this 'tradition'?

63.speaker: Lady Esther
63.text: The Society believes a githyanki raised in a peaceful, nurturing environment can overcome its violent nature.

98.speaker: Lady Esther
98.text: I'm sure your friend would agree. A githyanki is as likely to forsake its violent nature as a gnome is to fly.
98.context: CinematicNodeContext: Lae'zel looks pissed off - scowls & folds her arms

176.speaker: Lady Esther
176.text: Hogwash, of course. A githyanki can no more rise above its nature than gnomes can fly.

55.speaker: Player
55.text: Violence is taught, not inherited. You don't need to steal a child to know that.

152.speaker: Lady Esther
152.text: You've been sipping from the same goblet as the Society. Perhaps you'd be willing to help, then? To prove your point.

94.speaker: Player
94.text: Some things are in our blood - only a fool would deny that.

109.speaker: Lady Esther
109.text: Exactly! I knew you were a learned soul from the moment I set eyes on you.

162.speaker: Player
162.text: Well, you failed to get the egg, so I guess we'll never know.

103.speaker: Player
103.text: They used to think my people were inherently evil too, you know.

76.speaker: Lady Esther
76.text: Well, yes, but now we know better. Only some of you are bloodthirsty terrors.

126.speaker: Lady Esther
126.text: But if you believe in this cause so strongly, why not help the society prove your point?

42.speaker: Lady Esther
42.text: They may have chased me away, but surely the gith would welcome a person with such sympathetic views to their crèche.

65.speaker: Player
65.text: Well, with the right application of force and lift it could be possible...

239.speaker: Player
239.text: A flying gnome. I'd need an airfoil, of course. And a source of propulsion.

233.speaker: Lady Esther
233.text: ...Look, I just need someone to fetch me a gith egg. Can you do that?

51.speaker: Player
51.text: I said it's a pity you didn't get the egg.

157.speaker: Lady Esther
157.text: Perhaps you could help me, then? I may not be welcome there, but surely a person with your charm and worldliness could get into the crèche.

223.speaker: Lady Esther
223.text: And once inside, you could simply... purloin an egg.

159.speaker: Player
159.text: With a pure will and great courage - anyone can rise above their nature.

177.speaker: Player
177.text: Violence is taught, not inherited. I would know - I received impeccable training.

242.speaker: Lady Esther
242.text: They have the audacity to call that hole a crèche, as if it weren't actually a murderous training camp.

151.speaker: Lady Esther
151.text: It may look like a peaceful, ruined temple, but it is overrun with brutish, stupid, rude githyanki.
151.context: NodeContext: Again, most offended by the face that they're rude

21.speaker: Player
21.text: Lady, I'm busy. What do you want?

50.speaker: Lady Esther
50.text: All business? Very well, I can respect that.

27.speaker: Lady Esther
27.text: Inside that temple is a gith crèche. The githyanki established it in what remained after they slaughtered all of the monks.

132.speaker: Lady Esther
132.text: But I'm not here to seek revenge for the deaths they caused.

174.speaker: Lady Esther
174.text: The Society of Brilliance tasked me with acquiring one of their eggs in order to settle a dispute.

123.speaker: Lady Esther
123.text: I have been... less than successful, and if the gith ever see me again, they will kill me. So, I'm asking you to retrieve an egg for me.

75.speaker: Player
75.text: Looks like a monastery to Lathander. What's your problem with the God of the Dawn?

86.speaker: Lady Esther
86.text: Oh I mean no offence to the Morninglord, I simply prefer when his monasteries aren't overrun with brutish, stupid, rude githyanki.

150.speaker: Player
150.text: Scalable architecture, good vantage points. Looks empty - perfect ambush spot.

121.speaker: Lady Esther
121.text: Thank you so much. Do be sure to pop into the Lodge should you ever visit Baldur's Gate.

124.speaker: Lady Esther
124.text: What news of our little project? Have you found the egg?

13.speaker: Player
13.text: Calling it our project seems like a bit of a stretch.

66.speaker: Lady Esther
66.text: Now now, no need to get out of humour. Manners are everything.

47.speaker: Lady Esther
47.text: Well, I would advise you work on it in the actual crèche. Dawdling here helps no one.

256.speaker: Lady Esther
256.text: Very well, but I'll make note of how much time you waste trawling through baubles.

156.speaker: Player
156.text: You can't have the egg - I won't support this revolting experiment.

225.speaker: Lady Esther
225.text: I'm sorry? You think you can take my money and then just back out? I will not be robbed by the likes of you!
225.context: NodeContext: Combat starts after this line.

138.speaker: Lady Esther
138.text: Shame that monastery had to go up like that - taking my impeccable reputation for success with it.

226.speaker: Player
226.text: You're in luck - I've got the githyanki egg you were looking for.

146.speaker: Lady Esther
146.text: Did you see that? The entire building - rubble! I bet it took the crèche too. This is a disaster!
146.context: NodeContext: Upset that your mission to get an egg has been ruined

209.speaker: Player
209.text: How did you know there was a crèche in there?

12.speaker: Lady Esther
12.text: I was here on business, before it was blown to Mount Celestia.

60.speaker: Player
60.text: Did you have friends in the crèche?

3.speaker: Lady Esther
3.context: NodeContext: Insulted/amused that the player thinks you might have had gith friends

28.speaker: Lady Esther
28.text: I needed a githyanki egg. Contractual business. That blast probably left it as a rather messy scramble.

200.speaker: Player
200.text: Why did you want a githyanki egg?

218.speaker: Lady Esther
218.text: It's for the Society of Brilliance. Clever lot, but they're convinced they can raise a githyanki child to be good.

204.speaker: Lady Esther
204.text: Alas, I shall have to search for that egg elsewhere now.

235.speaker: Player
235.text: I have your egg. Take it.

74.speaker: Lady Esther
74.text: Fortuitous indeed! You shall be rewarded immediately!
74.context: CinematicNodeContext: Character reaches behind back to retrieve item from inventory - hand over is off camera

61.speaker: Lady Esther
61.text: Thank you. Paying upfront seems to have had its benefits.

19.speaker: Lady Esther
19.text: A pleasure to do business with you.

236.speaker: Player
236.text: I found an egg, but destroyed it.

168.speaker: Lady Esther
168.text: You held my success in your hands only to stomp on it, and report it to me with glee? I will not be mocked!

202.speaker: Player
202.text: I blew it up. The crèche too.

31.speaker: Lady Esther
31.text: How... Uncouth. You've rather scuppered a project I was working on.

208.speaker: Lady Esther
208.text: Stop there! Not one step further!
208.context: NodeContext: First sentence partly under her breath to herself; second sentence loudly and somewhat patronising, as if she doesn't quite expect the player to understand the language

191.speaker: Lady Esther
191.text: I left your stupid crèche, why are you still chasing me? I don't even want your bloody eggs!

205.speaker: Player
205.text: Calm yourself, I am not chasing you.

264.speaker: Lady Esther
264.text: This could be an auspicious meeting, come to think of it. I was hoping to meet a friendly gith.

29.speaker: Lady Esther
29.text: Well not your eggs specifically, any gith egg...
29.context: NodeContext: full line "any gith egg would do", but you trail off because you realise the player isn't your enemy

34.speaker: Lady Esther
34.text: ...You're not from that crèche, are you?
34.context: NodeContext: Realising the player isn't your enemy. [YIL-ik]

190.speaker: Lae'zel
190.text: Nod your head, play along. Find out what you can, take her head when it's done.
190.context: NodeContext: Quietly aside to the player

167.speaker: Lady Esther
167.text: Oh how fortuitous! And not just because you're not trying to kill me. I was hoping to meet a friendly gith, actually.

120.speaker: Player
120.text: Sorry, who's trying to kill you?

67.speaker: Player
67.text: There's a crèche nearby? Direct me there at once.

194.speaker: Lady Esther
194.text: You - you're not from the crèche? Oh, how fortuitous! And not just because you're not trying to kill me.

214.speaker: Lady Esther
214.text: I would be happy to reveal its extremely secret location if you'd be willing to perform one small favour for me.

211.speaker: Player
211.text: What makes you think I'm friendly?

230.speaker: Lady Esther
230.text: I - uh - it's simply because you look so... pleasant.

0.speaker: Lady Esther
0.text: Look, I've already been threatened with death today so, relatively speaking, you seem nice. Can you help me?

62.speaker: Lady Esther
62.text: I was given a task, one surprisingly difficult for someone like me. And yet it would be simplicity itself for you!

149.speaker: Lady Esther
149.text: I need a githyanki egg - which I know may sound a little unsavoury -

245.speaker: Lae'zel
245.text: Shka'keth! You would steal away one of our children?

59.speaker: Lady Esther
59.text: How rude. This is exactly why you people have a bit of a reputation, you know.

70.speaker: Lady Esther
70.text: As I was trying to say, this is an entirely benevolent act and all for a very good cause.

80.speaker: Player
80.text: You want to steal away our young? Your head is mine for daring to suggest it.

43.speaker: Lady Esther
43.text: The best cause there is: knowledge!

195.speaker: Lady Esther
195.text: Inside that temple lies one of your 'crèches', which I gather has its very own hatchery, presumably chock full of eggs.
195.context:
CinematicNodeContext: She points to the Monestary of Lathander, which we can see in the distance

(Direction is forward and to the Expeditioner's right, roughly 2 o'clock)

251.speaker: Lady Esther
251.text: The Society of Brilliance have asked me to acquire one of your people's roe so they can incubate it and, once it hatches, raise it in their tradition.

49.speaker: Lady Esther
49.text: They believe a githyanki raised in a peaceful, nurturing environment can overcome its violent nature.
49.context: NodeContext: Subtly sceptical of this idea

136.speaker: Lady Esther
136.text: Bring me an egg I can deliver to the Society and you will be well rewarded.

7.speaker: Player
7.text: I'm amazed you escaped the crèche alive, frankly.

187.speaker: Lady Esther
187.text: I know! They were pure savages - not like you. I'm sure you would appreciate that this is all in the name of knowledge.

166.speaker: Player
166.text: Uh huh. And how much will I get?

72.speaker: Lady Esther
72.text: The Society of Brilliance supplied me with an ample purse to buy an egg for their studies. Bring me one and that purse is all yours.

106.speaker: Lae'zel
106.text: Steal one of Gith's own? I will slit your throat for even suggesting it.

96.speaker: Lady Esther
96.text: I am not talking to you.

160.speaker: Player
160.text: Punt the egg off the side of the cliff with a hearty kick.

186.speaker: Narrator
186.text: *Using every scrap of your concentration, you kick the egg just hard enough that it doesn't crack, but soars like a red dragon.*

241.speaker: Lady Esther
241.text: You brute, what have you done? You will pay for this!

232.speaker: Player
232.text: I already have an egg - here.

131.speaker: Lady Esther
131.text: You've had one the entire time and didn't say a word?

130.speaker: Lady Esther
130.text: You've already been generously compensated, so all I have left to offer is my thanks.

181.speaker: Lady Esther
181.text: Well, I suppose a spot of conversation never goes amiss. Here's your reward.
181.context: CinematicNodeContext: Character reaches behind back to retrieve item from inventory - hand over is off camera

89.speaker: Lady Esther
89.context: NodeContext: Starts thrilled, saying "oh you wonderful person", but then realises she's not looking at the gith egg she thought she was. This is a different kind of egg.

217.speaker: Lady Esther
217.text: It looks different to what I expected. Are you sure that's a gith egg?
217.context: NodeContext: Unsure what she's looking at

11.speaker: Player
11.text: No, it's an owlbear's. I just like it.

158.speaker: Lady Esther
158.text: Everyone needs a hobby, I suppose. But if you find a gith egg, do return it quickly. No matter how much you 'like' it.

145.speaker: Player
145.text: The curves, the colouration, the size - looks right to me.

117.speaker: Lady Esther
117.text: You're right, it does have a rather fabulous sheen. It's surprisingly beautiful.

122.speaker: Lady Esther
122.text: You've proven an exceptionally efficient friend today. I hope we can work together again.

238.speaker: Lady Esther
238.text: How excellent. Here is, as promised, your reward.
238.context: CinematicNodeContext: Character reaches behind back to retrieve item from inventory - hand over is off camera

73.speaker: Player
73.text: No, but this owlbear egg is worth much more. And it can all be yours.

2.speaker: Player
2.text: Of course not. It's from an owlbear. But I bet your employers won't know the difference.

227.speaker: Lady Esther
227.text: What the Society doesn't know won't hurt it, and we're left handsomely legacied either way.

46.speaker: Lady Esther
46.text: I rather like this plan. You have yourself an accord.

229.speaker: Lady Esther
229.text: What a creative solution. I hope we can work together again some day.

234.speaker: Lady Esther
234.text: Here's your payment. I'd hope it's enough to warrant your discretion too.
234.context: CinematicNodeContext: Character reaches behind back to retrieve item from inventory - hand over is off camera

54.speaker: Lady Esther
54.text: A rapscallion I can have grudging respect for. A bare-faced liar, on the other hand...
54.context: NodeContext: The player just lied to her, but she found them out

110.speaker: Lady Esther
110.text: Such conduct is distasteful. Don't come back without the right egg.
110.context: NodeContext: The player just lied to her, but she found them out

224.speaker: Lae'zel
224.text: What? Surrender an egg, and I will not stand for it.
224.context: NodeContext: Shocked that player is willing to go along with stealing a gith egg

260.speaker: Lady Esther
260.text: I see this being a highly prosperous partnership.

180.speaker: Lady Esther
180.text: A word of advice: avoid direct confrontation. Crèche-bound githyanki can be a deadly sort.

111.speaker: Player
111.text: Do you have any equipment worth trading?

189.speaker: Lady Esther
189.text: I should hope so! When adventure calls, I am always thoroughly prepared. Take a look.

164.speaker: Lady Esther
164.text: Now, I believe you have places to be.

90.speaker: Player
90.text: Fine, but I want payment. Up front.

36.speaker: Lady Esther
36.text: I suppose there is a reason I'm asking you to do it.

243.speaker: Lady Esther
243.text: Very well, here's the money. Now I expect a speedy delivery.
243.context: CinematicNodeContext: Character reaches behind back to retrieve item from inventory - hand over is off camera

155.speaker: Lady Esther
155.text: I'm afraid that's not how it works. Egg first - compensation later.

95.speaker: Player
95.text: What you suggest is revolting. I won't let you do this.

139.speaker: Lady Esther
139.text: Excuse me? Were you not listening? I am on a mission and I will not be stopped by the likes of you or your wretched gith!
139.context: NodeContext: Combat starts after this line.

1.speaker: Player
1.text: You know, killing you is going to be very, very satisfying.

222.speaker: Lady Esther
222.text: I knew I was right about you beasts.
222.context: NodeContext: Combat starts after this line.

97.speaker: Player
97.text: My friend is right: what you suggest is revolting and you need to die.

105.speaker: Player
105.text: I'm not getting involved in this.

141.speaker: Lady Esther
141.text: No, of course. Not enough blood letting for your taste, I imagine.

22.speaker: Lady Esther
22.text: Should you change your mind, you know where to find me.

253.speaker: Player
253.text: State your cause. I'll be the judge of how 'good' it is.

207.speaker: Lady Esther
207.text: I need a githyanki egg - which may sound a little unsavoury, but I swear this is all for an excellent cause.

107.speaker: Lady Esther
107.text: The gith that inhabit that crèche of course - stupid, brutish creatures. Not like you at all.

188.speaker: Lady Esther
188.text: In fact, maybe you'd be able to succeed where I... was less successful.
188.context: NodeContext: doesn't want to say "where I failed"

228.speaker: Lady Esther
228.text: Have you given any more thought to the retrieval of that githyanki egg?

215.speaker: Player
215.text: I have the egg right here. Take it.

135.speaker: Lady Esther
135.text: My, how fortuitous! Jolly good show cracking through that crèche, they had it guarded up to the gizzard!

199.speaker: Lady Esther
199.text: A reward is most assuredly in order.
199.context: CinematicNodeContext: Character reaches behind back to retrieve item from inventory - hand over is off camera

201.speaker: Lady Esther
201.text: Trusting you with payment up front was a good investment, it seems.

210.speaker: Player
210.text: Why exactly do you want this egg?

213.speaker: Lady Esther
213.text: To settle a debate. Nature or nurture.

148.speaker: Lady Esther
148.text: The Society of Brilliance believes that it's possible to raise a githyanki to be good.
148.context: NodeContext: doesn't believe this is possible (is racist)

39.speaker: Lady Esther
39.text: An awful proposition that must be disproven once and for all.

116.speaker: Player
116.text: No, but I'd be willing to trade - if you have anything worth trading?

197.speaker: Lady Esther
197.text: I might have a few trinkets worth a glance.

88.speaker: Lady Esther
88.text: Happy, are we? Very well, then.

125.speaker: Player
125.text: I think you're vile and I'd sooner die than see you get that egg.
